questionList.title: Alzheimer disease

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Alzheimer's disease.
Alzheimer disease: epidemiology, diagnostic criteria, risk factors and biomarkers.

questionList.questionText: A 55-year-old man comes to the office due to difficulty chewing food over the past 2 months.  The patient initially experienced coughing while drinking liquids and has recently had difficulty ingesting solid foods.  In addition, several people have told him they have difficulty understanding his speech.  Review of systems is positive for a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months.  The patient smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 14/min.  BMI is 24 kg/m2.  On examination, there is pooling of secretions in the oral cavity.  Involuntary muscle twitching is noted over the chin, tongue, and upper and lower limbs.  Power is 4/5 in both upper extremities.  Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ throughout.  Bilateral Babinski is present.  Mental and sensory examinations are normal.  Which of the following is most likely present in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with bulbar symptoms (eg, dysphagia, dysarthria), muscle wasting and fasciculations, and hyperreflexia with positive Babinski has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).  ALS is a progressive disease that results from degeneration of upper motor neurons (UMNs) (eg, motor nuclei in the precentral gyrus and their projections in the corticospinal tract and corticobulbar tract) and lower motor neurons (LMNs) (eg, cranial nerves, spinal nerves).

Because any motor neuron can be involved, the initial presentation may vary widely but typically includes weakness in multiple muscle groups, with both LMN (eg, muscle atrophy, fasciculations) and UMN (eg, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, upgoing Babinski) signs.  In 20% of patients, cranial nerves (eg, hypoglossal, ambiguus, motor trigeminal) are affected first, which results in bulbar symptoms (eg, coughing or choking when eating, weight loss); these patients have a worse prognosis.

(Choices A and B)  Disorders of the neuromuscular junction include myasthenia gravis, which results from antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors, and Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which results from antibodies against presynaptic Ca channels and is associated with malignancy (eg, weight loss, smoking history).  These disorders can present with asymmetric muscle weakness, including of the bulbar muscles.  However, symptoms are typically fluctuating, and, because they affect the neuromuscular junction, UMN signs would not be present.

(Choice C)  Brainstem compression can result in bulbar symptoms and UMN signs in the extremities.  However, compression would typically also affect other cranial nerves (eg, III, V, VII, XI) and would likely also affect the respiratory drive (due to medullary compression).  LMN signs such as fasciculations are not common with brainstem compression.

(Choice E)  Inflammatory myopathies (eg, polymyositis) cause widespread muscle weakness.  However, because they affect the musculature (rather than motor) neurons, hyporeflexia may occur but UMN signs (eg, hyperreflexia, abnormal Babinski) would be unexpected.

Educational objective:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis leads to degeneration of the upper motor neurons (eg, motor nuclei in the precentral gyrus and their projections in the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and lower motor neurons (eg, cranial nerves, spinal nerves).  Because any motor neuron can be involved, patients may have a variety of symptoms, including bulbar muscle weakness.  Examination shows both upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

questionList.questionText:
A 79-year-old woman is brought to the office due to recurrent falls.  Over the past year, the patient has become increasingly unsteady while walking and has had several falls.  The patient has had no headaches, vision changes, nausea, or vomiting.  Medical history is significant for hypertension, for which she takes losartan.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable.  Neurological examination shows normal cranial nerves and fundoscopy.  There is increased tone and hyperreflexia of the lower extremities.  Sensation to light touch and vibration is intact.  When instructed to walk, the patient moves slowly with small steps and a wide base; she takes several steps to turn around.  CT scan of the brain is shown below.

This patient's symptoms would most likely improve with which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with recurrent falls has hyperreflexia and a wide-based gait.  In association with the CT of the head demonstrating ventriculomegaly out of proportion to cerebral atrophy (eg, normal sulci), this presentation suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).  NPH is characterized by abnormal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) accumulation and results in increased ventricular size without persistent elevations in intracranial pressure.

Symptoms of NPH are classically described as a triad of urinary incontinence, cognitive impairment, and gait abnormalities.  However, all 3 features are not required for diagnosis; in fact, only gait dysfunction, typically the most prominent symptom, is mandatory.  In addition, upper-motor neuron signs, such as lower-extremity spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar responses, may occur.

The diagnosis is confirmed with high-volume lumbar puncture, which allows for both confirmation of normal opening pressure and gait testing.  Improvement of gait function after the CSF removal is diagnostic.  Alternatively, a temporary lumbar drain may be placed to assess for gait improvement over a period of days.  Definitive therapy is ventricular shunt placement to divert excess CSF into the abdomen (ventriculoperitoneal shunt) or heart (ventriculoatrial shunt).

(Choice A)  Acetazolamide is used to treat patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (ie, pseudotumor cerebri).  However, this typically occurs in young, obese women and is characterized by headache, vision change, and papilledema.  Ventriculomegaly and gait dysfunction are unexpected.

(Choice B)  Cholinesterase inhibitors (eg, donepezil) are used to treat Alzheimer dementia.  Despite generalized brain atrophy (eg, hydrocephalus ex vacuo) being common, ventriculomegaly without sulcal enlargement suggests NPH.  In addition, hyperreflexia is unexpected.

(Choice C)  High-dose glucocorticoids are used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis, which can cause upper motor neuron signs and falls but typically occurs in young women with relapsing and remitting symptoms rather than the progressive symptoms seen in this patient.  Ventriculomegaly is unexpected.

(Choice E)  Levodopa and carbidopa are used to treat Parkinson disease (PD), which can cause gait abnormalities.  However, although shuffling is common in PD, the gait is usually festinating (short, quick steps).  In addition, PD typically causes a pill-rolling tremor and cogwheel rigidity.

Educational objective:
Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by abnormal gait, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment; however, only gait dysfunction is required for diagnosis.  Neuroimaging demonstrates ventriculomegaly out of proportion to cerebral atrophy.  The diagnosis is confirmed with high-volume lumbar puncture demonstrating improvement of gait with cerebrospinal fluid removal.  Definitive treatment is ventricular shunt placement.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus

questionList.questionText: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the office by her son.  He reports that his mother has had periodic confusion, memory loss, and poor sleep and seems "kind of out of it sometimes."  These symptoms have gradually worsened over the past 1-2 years.  The patient occasionally sees "strangers in the backyard," who are not there when her son looks for them.  More recently, she has begun walking more slowly and has fallen twice in the past month without any significant injuries.  The patient has a history of hypertension and depression.  She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs.  On physical examination, she walks slowly and has mild bilateral hand tremors and mild bilateral lower limb rigidity.  On cognitive examination, the patient appears to be oriented to person and place, and can recall 1 of 3 items in 5 minutes; she can state the days of the week forward but does not cooperate with stating them backward.  Chemistries, complete blood count, vitamin B12, and thyroid function tests are normal.  Serum treponemal test is nonreactive.  MRI of the brain shows mild generalized cortical atrophy.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's 1- to 2-year history of periodic confusion accompanied by visual hallucinations and parkinsonian motor symptoms (eg, tremors, rigidity) is suggestive of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), the cause of 10%-20% of dementias in the United States.  DLB is characterized by alterations in consciousness, fluctuations in cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, and relatively early compromise of executive functions.  Repeated falls and sleep disturbance are characteristic.

At autopsy, Lewy bodies, eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions representing accumulations of alpha-synuclein protein, may be seen in neurons of the substantia nigra, locus coeruleus, dorsal raphe nucleus, and substantia innominata.  Pharmacotherapy of DLB consists of carbidopa-levodopa for parkinsonism and cholinesterase inhibitors for cognitive impairment.  If psychotic symptoms persist, a low-dose second-generation antipsychotic, rather than a first-generation antipsychotic, is preferred due to the severe neuroleptic sensitivity seen in these patients.

(Choice A)  Alzheimer disease typically presents with early and prominent memory loss.  The core clinical features of cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism in this patient make DLB more likely.

(Choice C)  Major depressive disorder is characterized by persistent depressed mood and syndromal neuro-vegetative symptoms.  Although mild cognitive impairment and psychotic features can occur in major depression, this patient's parkinsonism and fluctuating cognition would not be consistent with depression.

(Choice D)  Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by cognitive changes (eg, decreased attention and concentration, apathy), changes in gait, and urinary incontinence.  Visual hallucinations and sleep impairment are not common.  MRI characteristically shows ventriculomegaly that is out of proportion to the degree of sulcal widening.

(Choice E)  Lewy bodies are a pathologic finding also present in Parkinson disease.  The key distinction between these 2 conditions is the early appearance of cognitive fluctuations and dementia in DLB, whereas dementia occurs late in the course of Parkinson disease (much later than the emergence of motor symptoms).  In addition, visual hallucinations are not common in Parkinson disease unless they are due to dopaminergic medications given to treat the underlying illness.

Educational objective:
Dementia with Lewy bodies causes cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism.  Cognitive symptoms may precede, or appear along with, parkinsonian features.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Dementia with lewy bodies

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Lewy body disease:  clinical and pathological "overlap syndrome" between synucleinopathies (Parkinson disease) and tauopathies (Alzheimer disease).
Clinical presentation and differential diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies:  a review.

questionList.questionText: A 79-year-old man is brought to the office by his daughter because he has been losing weight and appears withdrawn.  The patient is a retired bus driver and has lived alone since his wife died 5 years ago.  The daughter reports that he has difficulty with meal preparation and requires frequent assistance with bathing and dressing.  The patient has fallen backward twice in the past 3 months and fears falling again.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  The patient appears withdrawn with low energy and has a monotonous, soft voice.  He sits with a stooped posture, dabs at his mouth with a handkerchief regularly, and has little facial expression.  He has a tremor in the right hand.  Which of the following additional examination findings is most likely in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Abnormal gait patterns

Parkinsonian
(PD, MSA, DLB, VD)

  • Narrow based
  • Shuffling (reduced stride length)

Weakness with spasticity
(myelopathy)

  • Narrow based
  • Scissoring
  • Toes scrape the floor

Myopathic
(myopathies, MG)

  • Waddling
  • Abnormal pelvic tilt (limb girdle weakness)

Magnetic
(NPH)

  • Difficulty initiating steps

Vestibular
(BPPV, Ménière disease)

  • Stumbling or veering to one side (usually the affected side)

Cerebellar ataxia
(stroke, drug toxicity,

alcohol, hereditary)

  • Wide based
  • Stumbling, lurching
  • May be one sided or bilateral depending on etiology

Sensory ataxia
(sensory neuropathy,

vitamin B12 deficiency)

  • Wide based
  • High stepping/stamping
  • Worse in the dark

BPPV = benign positional paroxysmal vertigo; DLB = dementia with Lewy bodies; MG = myasthenia gravis; MSA = multiple system atrophy; NPH = normal pressure hydrocephalus; PD = Parkinson disease; VD = vascular dementia.

This patient has an asymmetric resting hand tremor, masked facies (little facial expression), hypophonia (soft voice), drooling (frequently dabbing at the mouth), and a stooped posture.  This combination is strongly suspicious for parkinsonism.  Patients with parkinsonism have bradykinesia, sometimes called a "poverty of movement," that can manifest in the face (masked facies), the voice (hypophonia), and decreased swallowing strength and frequency (drooling).

Bradykinesia is often most obvious in the classic, hypokinetic gait, features of which often include the following:

  • A narrow base

  • Difficulty with initiation of gait  (If severe, this can result in freezing of gait, which is an inability to initiate at all.)

  • Short steps, which may result in shuffling (dragging the feet) or festination (progressive quickening of steps with shortening of strides)

  • Reduced arm movement (typically asymmetric)

  • En bloc turning (head, trunk, and legs all rotate together)

Falls are somewhat unusual in early idiopathic Parkinson disease, so this patient's history of early falls is concerning for an atypical parkinsonian disorder (ie, Parkinson-plus syndrome) such as multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, or corticobasal degeneration.

(Choices A and E)  A wide-based gait can be seen in either cerebellar or sensory ataxia.  Cerebellar ataxia results in stumbling or lurching that can be ipsilateral (ie, falling to one side).  In addition to a wide-based gait, patients with sensory ataxia often have a high-stepping, stamping gait, which may be an attempt to increase sensory feedback; it worsens significantly in the dark (decreased visual cues).

(Choice B)  A narrow-based, scissoring gait is caused by bilateral leg weakness (diplegia) with spasticity that results from upper motor neuron lesions (eg, cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury).  Hip flexor weakness requires hip circumduction to help the toes clear the ground; spasticity can result in leg scissoring (ie, crossing) due to increased tone in the hip adductors which tend to be stronger than the abductors.

(Choice D)  A waddling gait is classically caused by myopathic weakness.  Myopathies tend to impact the proximal muscles more than the distal; weakness of the pelvic girdle muscles (eg, iliopsoas, gluteus muscles) results in excessive pelvic tilt that shifts with each step, leading to a waddle.

Educational objective:
Parkinsonism often leads to a hypokinetic gait characterized by difficulty initiating steps, a narrow base, shuffling or festinating strides, asymmetrically reduced arm movement, and en bloc turning.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Parkinson disease

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Gait analysis in Parkinson's disease: an overview of the most accurate markers for diagnosis and symptoms monitoring.

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fall at home while walking to the kitchen.  Prior to the fall, the patient did not have lightheadedness, chest pain, or palpitations, and he did not hit his head or lose consciousness during the fall or afterward.  His wife says the patient has become increasingly weak over the past 6 months and has fallen several times.  The patient has also become forgetful, and his wife thinks he even forgets to go to the bathroom, as he has urinated on himself on several occasions.  He has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis.  The patient has never smoked but used to drink heavily until stopping 10 years ago.  Blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min with no orthostatic changes.  On physical examination, there is no carotid bruit, and cardiac examination is unremarkable.  Neurological examination shows normal cranial nerves and fundoscopy.  Bilateral lower extremity muscle strength is normal, but tone and reflexes are increased.  Sensation to light touch, pain, and vibration are intact.  Gait is slow and wide based, and the patient takes several small steps to turn around.  Mini-Mental State Examination score is 21 of 30.  Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questionList.explanationText:
This elderly patient with recurrent falls and memory impairment has the classic symptom triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH):

  • Gait dysfunction is often the most pronounced feature.  Patients typically take small steps in a broad-based gait, often described as appearing that the feet are stuck to the floor (magnetic gait).

  • Urinary incontinence is common and often of the urgency variety; however, incontinence with apathy occurs as the disease progresses.

  • Dementia typically occurs slowly over a period of years and is associated with apathy and impaired executive function.

Other common features include upper motor neuron signs (eg, hyperreflexia, spasticity, upgoing plantar reflexes).

NPH is characterized by enlargement of the ventricles (ventriculomegaly) out of proportion to the sulci on neuroimaging (eg, CT scan, MRI).  It is associated with reduced cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reabsorption, which may occur due to elevated central pressures or chronic periventricular ischemia.  The diagnosis is confirmed with improvement after high volume lumbar puncture or lumbar drain placement.  As the name suggests, the cerebrospinal fluid opening pressure is normal; elevated pressures should alert the physician to other possible pathologies.  The definitive treatment of NPH is placement of a ventricular shunt.

(Choice A)  This patient has a risk factor for vascular dementia (hypertension); however, the onset of vascular dementia typically occurs in a stepwise fashion (reflecting new strokes) rather than slowly progressive one.  In addition, patients tend to have a narrow-based, shuffling gait.

(Choice B)  Cord compression from vertebral metastases can cause upper motor neuron signs and incontinence, but it is typically associated with severe back pain and progressive lower extremity weakness and paralysis.

(Choice C)  Pseudotumor cerebri is caused by elevated intracranial pressure (eg, elevated opening pressure on lumbar puncture).  However, it is usually seen in young females with obesity and presents with headaches and double vision, not memory impairment; papilledema is expected on fundoscopic exam.

(Choice E)  Periodic sharp waves on electroencephalography are seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which can cause upper motor neuron signs and ataxia but manifests with rapid-onset dementia and myoclonus.  It is not commonly associated with urinary incontinence.

(Choice F)  Reactive VDRL on CSF analysis suggests neurosyphilis, which causes dementia but is often associated with pupillary abnormalities (eg, Argyll-Robertson pupils), sensory ataxia, and lancinating pains.  It is very rare due to widespread antibiotic use.

Educational objective:
Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the symptom triad of gait disturbance, dementia, and urinary incontinence; upper motor neuron signs may also occur.  Neuroimaging demonstrates enlargement of the ventricles out of proportion to the sulci.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus

answerChoiceList.choice: Clinically unrecognized infarctions on brain MRI
Cord compressing vertebral metastases on spine MRI
Elevated opening pressure on lumbar puncture
Large ventricles with normal sulci on CT scan of the brain
Periodic sharp wave complexes on electroencephalography
Reactive VDRL on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
